I will continue working w/ colleagues on both sides of the aisle to ensure that ignorance of how our state works does not give birth to future legal battles that serve to target Alaska Natives unfairly. 

Read more: https://donyoung.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=402018
Today is a tremendous victory for our state's First Peoples, but it was also a needlessly fought legal battle.
The time to express concerns over the bill was then, not weeks after its passage and enactment, and certainly not 15 months into the pandemic that necessitated this bill in the first place.
Here is the fact: The legislative text of the CARES Act was available out in the open throughout the drafting process before it went on to pass 96-0 in the Senate, and by voice vote in the House.
As the first-ever AK Native to hold this high-ranking position, she was unfairly targeted by those who have no idea how our state operates.
She did an outstanding job at Interior, but forces from the Lower 48, including Sen Chuck Schumer, launched defamatory personal attacks against her in the early days of this battle.

This entire legal battle was a true shame, and caused pain for many people. 

In particular, politics and misinformation brought slanderous attacks against then-Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs, Tara Katuk Sweeney. @tarasweeney907

This win in our nation's highest court was made possible through the grit and determination of Alaska Native advocates, a top-notch legal team, the State of Alaska, and the full support of the Alaska Delegation.

Those who do not understand the unique nature of ANCs have undermined Alaska's COVID-19 response, and put our vulnerable Native communities at risk; this obstruction ends today. 

I am pleased that the Supreme Court has sided with Alaska Natives.
COVID-19 hit our Alaska Native communities hard, and the impacts have only been compounded in our remote villages by poor sanitation infrastructure and sheer geography.

Alaska is unique; our Native people are served in a multitude of ways by Alaska Native Corporations, tribes, and tribal consortia. Unfortunately, for over a year, lawsuits from the Lower 48 have prevented ANCs from accessing the relief funds they desperately need.

It was imperative to us that all of our nation's Indigenous people qualified for aid, which is why a comprehensive definition of 'tribe' ‚Äì as defined under the half-century old Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act ‚Äì was used in the CARES Act.
While drafting the CARES Act, Congress worked hard to ensure that Alaska Native and other Indigenous communities received the support they needed to get through this pandemic.

The decision in Yellen v. Confederated Tribes of the Chehalis Reservation upholds congressional intent, and finally confirms that Alaska Native Corporations are eligible for COVID-19 relief funding authorized by the CARES Act.

Today, the Supreme Court affirmed what Alaska Native advocates and our Delegation have known all along: Alaska Native Corporations meet the definition of 'Indian tribe.' This is truly a great day for Alaska Native communities across our great state. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E4wKMnTXwAwsVm5.jpg
